Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Deformation Thermometry and Water Weakening of Quartz Tectonites - Case Studies from the Himalaya and the Caledonides of NW Scotland
Award.AbstractNarration:
Quantitative determination of the ambient temperatures at which rocks deform under different tectonic settings in the earth's crust is of critical importance for constraining thermo-mechanical modeling of the earth's tectonic plates, and their mechanical and thermal evolution. Ambient deformation temperatures control the physical processes that govern deformation and the rates at which deformation occurs. Pressure-Temperature-time (PTt) histories of rocks can be obtained from the compositions of minerals and mineral assemblages, through reaction equilibrium relations, but these determinations bear on the PT conditions of the mineral reactions, not necessarily those of deformation. Development of thermometers that directly constrain conditions of deformation is important because temperatures indicated by deformation features and those indicated by equilibrium mineral assemblages may differ, recording different intervals of a rock's PTt history. In quartz-rich continental crust, two types of deformation thermometers (based on quartz recrystallization processes and crystallographic fabrics) have been used as analytical tools over the last two decades in a wide range of tectonic studies, assuming that temperature is the primary controlling factor in recrystallization regime and fabric development. However, recrystallization regimes and fabric development may also be influenced by trace levels of water, and the effects of water on deformation mechanisms and fabric development may be of comparable importance to temperature. We propose to test, refine, and validate the deformation thermometers for quartz-bearing rocks and to examine those conditions under which water contents or variations in deformation rate need to be evaluated. We have chosen Himalayan and NW Scotland field areas as case studies because one of us has already collected extensive suites of appropriate oriented quartz-rich tectonites from these areas under prior NSF funding. These samples have been deformed under a wide range of tectonic settings and deformation thermometry, together with more restricted compositionally based thermometry, have already been completed on many of these samples. Deformation temperatures indicated by recrystallization regime and crystallographic fabrics in individual samples will be independently compared/tested by titanium-in-quartz thermometry, while the potential influence of water on recrystallization and crystallographic fabrics will be investigated by infrared spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy.

Integration of theoretical concepts and analytical techniques developed in Geosciences and Materials Science over the last half century has led to major advances in our understanding of both the mechanisms by which rocks deform/flow and the influence of environmental factors such as temperature on flow in the earth's crust. However the most commonly applied analytical techniques for determining the temperatures at which rocks now exposed at the earth's surface have been deformed are known to also be sensitive to fluctuations in chemically-induced weakening that may have occurred during deformation in the mineral grains making up the rock. Thus, deformation temperatures calculated using these thermometers may be in error, and thermomechanical numerical models developed to simulate flow in the crust using such temperature data may give unrealistic results. This project is designed to test the validity of these thermometers using a recently developed thermometer that takes such chemical processes in to account. Rock samples collected under previous NSF funding from ancient mountain belts in the Himalaya and Scotland have been chosen as case studies, and the potential role of chemical weakening in these samples will also be evaluated using complementary analytical techniques. These studies have important applications to plate tectonics and the results may change our understanding of the mechanical and thermal character of plates. Plate thickness and strength were originally considered to be due solely to temperature and the geothermal gradient in the earth. Our study addresses this concept and tests whether the internal strength of plates may also be influenced by water content, in addition to temperature. The project is a collaborative effort between researchers at Virginia Tech, Texas A&M University and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. In addition to the scientific goals of the project, this research is contributing to the training of Ph.D. students at Virginia Tech and Texas A&M, and providing support for an early career post-doctoral researcher at RPI. Undergraduate students at all of the participating institutions will be involved in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Displacements on major faults that cross-cut the lithosphere, the outer region of the Earth consisting of tectonic plates, depend on frictional sliding along fault surfaces at shallow crustal depths and plastic flow of quartz (and other minerals) at deep crustal depths.  This research addresses the plastic flow properties of quartz and the conditions for its deformation at middle to lower crustal depths, by reexamining fault rock textures, evaluating temperatures of deformation, and exploring the role of water in deformation of fault zones uplifted and exposed in the Himalaya and Caledonide mountain belts.  The primary goals of the collaborative research conducted at Texas A&M University include the measurement of water contents of deformed quartz in well-characterized faults, comparison of their water contents with those of quartz deformed under controlled laboratory conditions, characterization of water incorporation at the microscopic scale, and the interpretation of plastic flow strengths of quartz and water weakening in the Earth’s middle to lower crust.  All of the faults studied appear to have served as conduits for fluid flow in the Earth’s lithosphere during deformation, and their mechanical properties appear to have been governed by water weakening of quartz, a process that is well documented in laboratory experiments but little explored in naturally deformed rocks of the Earth’s lithosphere.

Water in quartz grains has been studied by infrared (IR) spectroscopy, measuring hydrogen-oxygen stretching vibrations, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), imaging fine scale fluid inclusions, for samples collected from the Moine Thrust of the NW Scotland Caledonide mountain belt, and the Main Central Thrust (in NW India) and the South Tibetan Detachment System (north of Mt Everest) of the Himalayan mountain belt.  All of these fault zones show quartz textures characteristic of extensive high temperature flow associated with the tectonic fault displacements.  IR spectra reveal crystalline hydrogen defects in the deformed quartz grains, as well as evidence of microscopic fluid inclusions and micas.  TEM images reveal relationships between the fluid inclusions and crystalline defects responsible for plastic flow.

Moine Thrust quartzites deformed at temperatures T of ~350oC characteristic of middle crustal conditions.  IR spectra indicate that water weakening of these rocks occurred by the same mechanisms as reported in laboratory deformation experiments.  Water contents vary with structural level within this fault zone, with contents that decrease from ~4000 parts per million (ppm, molar concentration of OH per Si) at 70 m below the thrust fault to ~1500 ppm at the fault surface.  These concentrations appear to be reduced by recrystallization of quartz that occurred during deformation.  The highest water contents correspond to quartzites with just 17% recrystallized grains, while the lowest water contents at the thrust fault surface are measured for fully recrystallized (97%) quartz.  As a result, some hardening of the fault zone is implied.   However, even the lowest water contents of Moine Thrust samples are sufficient for water weakening, and lab-based flow laws applied to the natural conditions of this fault predict low flow strength.

Deformation of quartz in the Main Central Thrust of the Himalayan mountain belt occurred at the much higher temperatures (T of ~600oC) of the lower crust, and trends of water content with structural level and deformation textures are more complex.  In some regions, water weakening of quartz is apparent (with quartz water contents of up to ~3000 ppm), while some regions appear to have lost fluids during deformation and recrystallization, reducing quartz water contents (to ~50-170 ppm) and leading to fault hardening.  Deformation of quartz in the South Tibetan Detachment System of the Himalayan mountain belt also occurred at high temperatures of the lower crust, but quartz grains of this fault zone have far higher water contents associated with the infiltration of meteoric waters from the Earth’s surface.  Water contents of these rocks are very large (>11,000 ppm) and predicted flow strengths are low.

The results of IR spectroscopy have been supplemented by TEM to examine fluid inclusions at high magnifications, and document their interactions with structural defects responsible for plastic flow.  Fluid inclusions, 30 nm to 2 microns in size, are common in deformed quartz grains with large hydrogen-oxygen absorption bands.  Moreover, they show intimate microstructural relationships with structural line defects known as dislocations that are similar to those observed in wet forms of quartz deformed in the laboratory under controlled conditions.
